A Frenchman named Casimir Lefaucheaux developed the original pinfire mechanism in 1828 and patented the pinfire cartridge in 1835. Historically, the pinfire cartridge was one of the reasons for the decline of muzzle-loading weapons. It was much quicker and easier to load a breech-loading weapon using pinfire cartridges. The pinfire cartridges were the First Metallic cartridges. On one side of the cartridge is a protruding firing pin (see pictures). The other end of the pin touches a small copper cap containing a pressure sensitive primer. The rest of the case is filled with gunpowder and there is a lead bullet at the end. To ignite the gunpowder charge, one applies a sharp blow to the pin. The other end of the pin then strikes the primer which then ignites and then burns the main gunpowder charge. To load a pinfire weapon, the user opens the breech of the gun and drops in a cartridge. There is a slot at the top so that the pin can protrude out of the slot. The user then cocks the hammer. When the user pulls the trigger, the hammer is released onto the pin, thereby firing the weapon.
